data.name: Angelika Amon
data.description: Angelika Amon examines cell growth and division, and how errors in this process contribute to cancer and aging.

data.name: Tania A. Baker
data.description: Tania Baker’s current research explores mechanisms and regulation of enzyme-catalyzed protein unfolding, ATP-dependent protein degradation, and remodeling of the proteome during cellular stress responses.

data.name: David Bartel
data.description: David Bartel studies molecular pathways that regulate eukaryotic gene expression by affecting the stability or translation of mRNAs.

data.name: Stephen Bell
data.description: Graduate Officer

data.name: Laurie A. Boyer
data.description: Laurie A. Boyer investigates the gene regulatory mechanisms that drive heart development and regeneration using embryonic stem cells and mouse models.

data.name: Christopher Burge
data.description: Christopher Burge applies a combination of experimental and computational approaches to understand the regulatory codes underlying pre-mRNA splicing and other types of post-transcriptional gene regulation.

data.name: Eliezer Calo
data.description: Eliezer Calo studies how cells build ribosomes and how dysfunction in ribosome biogenesis and function leads to tissue-specific developmental disorders and cancer.

data.name: Iain M. Cheeseman
data.description: Iain Cheeseman analyzes the process by which cells duplicate, focusing on the molecular machinery that segregates the chromosomes.

data.name: Jianzhu Chen
data.description: Jianzhu Chen studies the immune system, harnessing the body’s defense force to explore cancer treatment and vaccine development.

data.name: Sallie (Penny) W. Chisholm
data.description: Sallie (Penny) W. Chisholm studies the biology, ecology, and evolution of the single most abundant marine phytoplankton species in order to understand the forces that shape microbial ecosystems.

data.name: Martha Constantine-Paton
data.description: Professor Emerita

data.name: Joseph (Joey) Davis
data.description: Joey Davis investigates how cells maintain a delicate internal balance of assembling and dismantling their own machinery — in particular, assemblages of many molecules known as macromolecular complexes.

data.name: Catherine Drennan
data.description: Undergrad Officer

data.name: Gerald R. Fink
data.description: Gerald R. Fink investigates how fungal pathogens invade the body, evade the immune system, and establish an infection.

data.name: Mary Gehring
data.description: Graduate Officer

data.name: Frank Gertler
data.description: Frank B. Gertler considers the role of cell shape and movement in developmental defects and diseases.

data.name: Alan D. Grossman
data.description: Department Head

data.name: Leonard P. Guarente
data.description: Leonard P. Guarente looks at mammal, mouse, and human brains to understand the genetic underpinning of aging and age-related diseases like Alzheimer’s.

data.name: Michael T. Hemann
data.description: Michael T. Hemann uses mouse models to combat cancers resistant to chemotherapy.

data.name: Nancy Hopkins
data.description: Professor Emerita

data.name: H. Robert Horvitz
data.description: H. Robert Horvitz analyzes the roles of genes in animal development and behavior, gaining insight into human disease.

data.name: David Housman
data.description: David Housman studies the biological underpinnings of diseases like Huntington’s, cancer, and cardiovascular disease.

data.name: Richard O. Hynes
data.description: Richard O. Hynes investigates the network of proteins surrounding cells to understand its roles in the spread of cancer throughout the body.

data.name: Barbara Imperiali
data.description: Barbara Imperiali studies the biogenesis and myriad functions of glycoconjugates in human health and disease.

data.name: Tyler Jacks
data.description: Tyler Jacks is interested in the genetic events contributing to the development of cancer, and his group has created a series of mouse strains engineered to carry mutations in genes known to be involved in human cancers.

data.name: Rudolf Jaenisch
data.description: Rudolf Jaenisch uses pluripotent cells (ES and iPS cells) to study the genetic and epigenetic basis of human diseases such as Parkinson’s, Alzheimer’s, autism and cancer.

data.name: Ankur Jain
data.description: Ankur Jain investigates the role of RNA self-assembly in cellular organization and neurodegenerative disease.

data.name: Chris A. Kaiser
data.description: Chris A. Kaiser analyzes protein folding and trafficking in cells.

data.name: Amy E. Keating
data.description: Graduate Officer

data.name: Dennis Kim
data.description: Visiting Professor

data.name: Jonathan A.  King
data.description: Jonathan A. King studies what happens when proteins do not fold properly — leading to conditions like cataracts — and works to protect the conditions needed to support biomedical research.

data.name: Monty Krieger
data.description: Monty Krieger studies cell surface receptors and cholesterol and their impact on normal physiology and diseases, such as heart disease and infertility.

data.name: Rebecca Lamason
data.description: Rebecca Lamason investigates what happens when cellular functions are hijacked by unwanted interlopers: namely, the bacteria that engender diseases like spotted fever and meningitis.

data.name: Eric S. Lander
data.description: Eric S. Lander is interested in every aspect of the human genome and its application to medicine.

data.name: Michael T. Laub
data.description: Associate Dept. Head

data.name: Douglas Lauffenburger
data.description: Douglas Lauffenburger fosters the interface of bioengineering, quantitative cell biology, and systems biology to determine fundamental aspects of cell dysregulation — identifying and testing new therapeutic ideas.

data.name: Jacqueline Lees
data.description: Associate Dept. Head

data.name: Gene-Wei Li
data.description: Gene-Wei Li investigates how quantitative information regarding precise proteome composition is encoded in and extracted from bacterial genomes.

data.name: Pulin Li
data.description: Pulin Li is interested in quantitatively understanding how genetic circuits create multicellular behavior in both natural and synthetically engineered systems.

data.name: Troy Littleton
data.description: Troy Littleton is interested in how neuronal connections form and function, and how neurological disease disrupts synaptic communication.

data.name: Harvey F. Lodish
data.description: Harvey F. Lodish studies the development of red blood cells and the use of modified red cells for the introduction of novel therapeutics into the human body, as well as the development of brown and white fat cells.

data.name: Sebastian Lourido
data.description: Sebastian Lourido exposes parasite vulnerabilities and harnesses them to treat infectious disease.

data.name: Adam C. Martin
data.description: Undergrad Officer

data.name: Elly Nedivi
data.description: Elly Nedivi studies the mechanisms underlying brain circuit plasticity — characterizing the genes and proteins involved, as well as visualizing synaptic and neuronal remodeling in the living mouse brain.

data.name: Terry Orr-Weaver
data.description: Professor Emerita

data.name: David C. Page
data.description: David C. Page examines the genetic differences between males and females — and how these play out in disease, development, and evolution.

data.name: Mary-Lou Pardue
data.description: Professor Emerita

data.name: William (Chip) Quinn
data.description: Professor Emeritus

data.name: Uttam  RajBhandary
data.description: Uttam RajBhandary's interests include interactions between RNAs and proteins, focusing on gene expression and gene regulation.

data.name: Peter Reddien
data.description: Associate Dept. Head

data.name: Aviv Regev
data.description: Aviv Regev pioneers the use of single-cell genomics and other techniques to dissect the molecular networks that regulate genes, define cells and tissues, and influence health and disease.

data.name: David Sabatini
data.description: David Sabatini studies the pathways that regulate growth and metabolism and how they are deregulated in diseases like cancer and diabetes.

data.name: Leona Samson
data.description: Professor Emerita

data.name: Robert T. Sauer
data.description: Bob Sauer studies intracellular proteolytic machines responsible for protein-quality control and homeostasis.

data.name: Paul Schimmel
data.description: Professor Emeritus

data.name: Thomas U. Schwartz
data.description: Thomas U. Schwartz investigates communication across biological membranes, using structural, biochemical, and genetic tools.

data.name: Edward Scolnick
data.description: Emeritus Faculty

data.name: Phillip A. Sharp
data.description: Phillip A. Sharp studies many aspects of gene expression in mammalian cells, including transcription, the roles of non-coding RNAs, and RNA splicing.

data.name: Anthony J. Sinskey
data.description: Anthony J. Sinskey explores the principles of metabolic engineering in both bacteria and plants.

data.name: Hazel Sive
data.description: Hazel Sive studies fundamental mechanisms underlying vertebrate face and brain formation, as well as the molecular underpinnings for neurodevelopmental disorders.

data.name: Frank Solomon
data.description: Frank Solomon teaches undergraduates, graduate students, postdoctoral scholars, and MSRP participants in the areas of cell biology, experimental design, and responsible conduct of research.

data.name: Stefani Spranger
data.description: Stefani Spranger studies how the body’s immune system interacts with growing tumors to harness the immune response to fight cancer.

data.name: Lisa A. Steiner
data.description: Before closing her lab, Lisa A. Steiner analyzed the zebrafish genome to understand white blood cells and their role in the immune system.

data.name: JoAnne Stubbe
data.description: Professor Emerita

data.name: Susumu Tonegawa
data.description: Susumu Tonegawa investigates the biological underpinnings of learning and memory in rodents.

data.name: Matthew Vander Heiden
data.description: Matthew Vander Heiden is interested in the role that cell metabolism plays in mammalian physiology, with a focus on cancer.

data.name: Seychelle M. Vos
data.description: Seychelle M. Vos investigates how genome organization and gene expression are physically coupled across molecular scales.

data.name: Graham C. Walker
data.description: Graham C. Walker studies DNA repair, mutagenesis, and cellular responses to DNA damage, as well as the symbiotic relationship between legumes and nitrogen-fixing bacteria.

data.name: Bruce Walker
data.description: Bruce Walker investigates cellular immune responses in chronic human viral infections, with a particular focus on HIV immunology and vaccine development.

data.name: Robert A. Weinberg
data.description: Robert A. Weinberg studies how cancer spreads, what gives cancer stem-cells their unique qualities, and the molecular players involved in the formation of cancer stem cells and metastases.

data.name: Jing-Ke  Weng
data.description: Jing-Ke Weng studies metabolic evolution in plants and explores the remarkable plant chemodiversity for new commodity chemicals and medicines.

data.name: Matthew A. Wilson
data.description: Matthew Wilson studies rodent learning and memory by recording and manipulating the activity of neurons during behavior and sleep.

data.name: Michael B. Yaffe
data.description: Michael B. Yaffe studies the chain of reactions that controls a cell’s response to stress, cell injury, and DNA damage.

data.name: Omer H. Yilmaz
data.description: Omer H. Yilmaz explores the impact of dietary interventions on stem cells, the immune system, and cancer within the intestine.

data.name: Richard A. Young
data.description: Richard A. Young explores how and why gene expression differs in healthy versus diseased cells.
